column5:
Parisar Samvad Delhi is the dialogue and civic engagement node of Students Islamic Organisation (SIO) Delhi, focused on creating spaces for meaningful conversation on social, environmental, and public issues. The platform encourages dialogue as a tool for understanding, collaboration, and responsible citizenship.

As a node of SIO Delhi, Parisar Samvad works to promote constructive discussions, public dialogues, seminars, and interactive engagements on concerns that affect society at large—ranging from environmental responsibility and urban challenges to social harmony and ethical public discourse. It brings together students, academics, activists, and community voices to engage with issues through dialogue rather than polarisation.

Parisar Samvad believes that dialogue is essential for a healthy society. Through its initiatives, it aims to nurture informed perspectives, civic sensitivity, and a culture of listening—supporting SIO Delhi’s broader vision of conscious, engaged, and socially responsible student leadership.

column3: Beyond Tokenism: Where is the ‘Muslim Question’ in JNUSU Elections?
column5:
Jawaharlal Nehru University has long stood as a symbol of resistance against the majoritarian Hindutva regime. As a democratic space, JNU and the JNU Students’ Union have historically played an important role in shaping national discourses. In these tough times, when universities—especially Muslim institutions—are under systematic attack, JNU has also been a consistent target of state repression.

SIO, as a nationwide student organization, has stood with JNU in its struggles, consistently raising its voice in solidarity. As the JNUSU elections approach, we believe there are some urgent and critical questions to be posed before all political groups in JNU. These questions have emerged from the margins, from the lived experiences of Muslims, and from the increasing suffocation that surrounds their existence in this country.

Muslims in India are going through perhaps the most difficult phase in post-independence history. Since 2014, the BJP-led Hindutva government has accelerated its agenda of pushing Muslims out of public spaces—socially, politically, culturally, and economically. From the CAA–NRC to the Waqf (Amendment) Act, the state has made its intentions clear to systematically marginalize, de-legitimize, and invisibilize Muslims from the national fabric.

The Muslim question in India today is not just another case of marginalization—it is a crisis rooted in the struggle for dignity, faith, and the fundamental right to exist and dissent without fear. It goes beyond demands for representation or reservations; it is about living as a Muslim in public life without humiliation or criminalization. We urge all political groups contesting the JNUSU elections, especially the Left, Liberal, and Dalit groups, to move beyond symbolic gestures like donning a keffiyeh or offering token representation.

SIO JNU

column4:
Students Islamic Organisation of India (SIO) is an ideological organization working in the country since its inception on 19th October 1982 for the social progress and development of the students’ fraternity. It is SIO’s endeavor to prepare Students and Youth for the reconstruction of the society in the light of Divine guidance.

In order to understand SIO, it is essential to have a good grasp on its views on Islam, student and organization. The Arabic word Islam signifies peace, dedication and absolute submission. In other words it is the path to peace through complete surrender to God.

column5:
Fahem Reading Club is the reading and intellectual development node of Students Islamic Organisation (SIO) Delhi, established to cultivate a strong culture of reading, reflection, and critical inquiry among students. Fahem provides a structured space for engaging with books, ideas, and texts that shape thought, character, and worldview.

As a node of SIO Delhi, Fahem focuses on collective reading, book discussions, study circles, and guided intellectual engagements covering literature, history, social issues, philosophy, and contemporary concerns. The club encourages participants not just to read, but to understand, analyse, and question, fostering intellectual clarity and depth.

Fahem believes that informed minds are essential for meaningful change. Through its activities, the reading club aims to develop disciplined readers, thoughtful speakers, and socially aware individuals—contributing to SIO Delhi’s larger mission of conscious student leadership and constructive societal engagement.

column4: SIO Delhi commemorated the 43rd Foundation Day of the Students Islamic Organisation of India by reflecting on its decades-long journey of student activism, ethical leadership, and nation-building. The occasion served as a moment to revisit the organisation’s vision, ideological foundations, and continued commitment to nurturing socially responsible and value-driven youth. Through programs, discussions, and outreach activities, members and associates reaffirmed their dedication to the ideals of justice, integrity, and constructive engagement, carrying forward SIO’s legacy with renewed clarity and purpose.

SIO Delhi organized Maulana Maududi Lecture–09 as part of its ongoing intellectual and educational initiatives aimed at engaging students and youth with contemporary ideas rooted in Islamic thought. The lecture revisited the intellectual legacy of Syed Abul A‘la Maududi (رحمه الله), focusing on his insights into society, ethics, and the role of Islam in addressing modern challenges. Through critical reflection and discussion, the session encouraged participants to think beyond ritualistic understanding and engage Islam as a comprehensive, transformative worldview. The lecture served as a platform to inspire clarity of thought, ideological confidence, and socially responsible action among the youth.

The Summer Islamic Camp organized by Students Islamic Organisation (SIO), Delhi is a Summer Islamic Camp 2025purposeful initiative aimed at nurturing the intellectual, spiritual, and moral development of young minds during the summer break. In a time when distractions are many, the camp provides a healthy, value-based environment where participants can grow with clarity, confidence, and consciousness of their responsibilities as individuals and members of society.

column3: SIO Delhi Strongly Condemns the Brutal Attack on Students at Delhi University
column5:
SIO Delhi strongly condemns the unprovoked attack and detention of students by ABVP members and the Delhi Police during a peaceful solidarity gathering for Palestine today at the University of Delhi. A joint protest was scheduled to commence from the Arts Faculty, where students from various organizations, including SIO, Fraternity Movement, and other student organizations were to assemble in support of the people of Palestine and to demand an end to the ongoing genocide in Gaza.

SIO Delhi unequivocally condemns this act of violence and repression. We call for the immediate release of all detained students and demand accountability from the authorities responsible for this shameful act. SIO Delhi reaffirms its commitment to stand with the oppressed people of Palestine and its resolve to defend the democratic right to protest within university spaces.
sakjzfougaesZ

column3: Naqsh - Forum for Art and Culture
column5:
Naqsh Forum for Art & Culture is a creative and intellectual platform that brings together art, culture, and critical thought as tools of expression and social engagement. Inspired by the idea of naqsh—a lasting imprint—Naqsh seeks to create meaningful cultural narratives that resonate beyond the moment.

The forum provides space for artists, writers, filmmakers, designers, poets, and performers to explore ideas, question realities, and reflect society through diverse artistic forms. By encouraging dialogue through creativity, Naqsh nurtures a culture that is conscious, rooted, and responsive to its social context.

Through exhibitions, discussions, performances, screenings, and collaborative projects, Naqsh promotes art as a medium of awareness, resistance, and imagination, especially among young minds. It values authenticity over spectacle and substance over noise.

As a node of SIO Delhi, Naqsh Forum strengthens the organization’s cultural engagement by integrating creativity with purpose—using art not merely as aesthetics, but as a language to express identity, justice, and human values.

column4: SIO Delhi proudly hosted the Student Youth Conference as part of SIO India’s nationwide campaign “Soul Spark: Illuminate Ethics.”

column3: Ramadan is the month of compassion || Dr. Khan Yasir

column5:
Mohammad Saad Inam serves as the Media Secretary of SIO Delhi and a Bachelor’s student of Mass Communication. He is a media professional with practical experience in graphic design, video editing, and digital media production, actively involved in managing SIO Delhi’s visual identity, social media presence, and communication strategy.

With a background in creative design and content development, he has worked on media campaigns, publications, and digital initiatives aimed at effective outreach and public engagement. His work focuses on building clear, impactful narratives that align with SIO Delhi’s values while responding thoughtfully to contemporary social and media challenges.

Ayyamam Ma‘dudaat is a special Ramadan video series curated by SIO Delhi to spiritually engage students and youth during the blessed month of Ramadan. The series focuses on reflection, self-purification, consistency in worship, and ethical living, drawing inspiration from the Qur’an and Prophetic guidance. Released throughout Ramadan, the videos aim to help viewers make conscious use of these “counted days” by strengthening faith, discipline, and social responsibility. Through concise messages and thoughtful presentation, Ayyamam Ma‘dudaat serves as a digital companion for meaningful Ramadan engagement and post-Ramadan continuity.

We are deeply saddened by the tragic loss of lives in the Jaitpur wall collapse. Our heartfelt condolences go out to the families who lost their loved ones. May they find strength in this difficult time, and may the departed souls rest in eternal peace. Our thoughts and prayers are with all those affected by this tragedy.

column4: SIO Delhi organized a Workshop on Psycho-Spiritual Wellbeing to address the growing emotional, mental, and spiritual challenges faced by students and youth in contemporary times. The workshop focused on understanding inner wellbeing through a balanced integration of psychological awareness and spiritual grounding. Through guided discussions, reflective exercises, and expert insights, participants explored themes such as emotional resilience, self-awareness, stress management, and spiritual mindfulness. The session aimed to equip attendees with practical tools to nurture inner stability, purpose, and ethical living while navigating academic, personal, and social pressures.

column3: SIO Delhi Condemns Suspension of Jamia Faculty Member Virendra Balaji Shahare
column5:
The Students Islamic Organisation of India (SIO), Delhi Zone, expresses serious concern over the suspension of a faculty member of Jamia Millia Islamia for including a question on the condition of Muslim minorities in India in an examination paper.

SIO Delhi believes that discussing social realities, injustice, and minority issues is an essential part of academic study, especially in a subject like Social Problems in India. Penalising a teacher for encouraging critical thinking is an attack on academic freedom and democratic values.

We urge the university to revoke the suspension, ensure a fair inquiry, and protect the autonomy of educational institutions. Universities must remain spaces for free thought, dialogue, and truth — not fear.

SIO Delhi

Naqsh Forum for Art & Culture is the art and cultural node of Students Islamic Organisation (SIO) Delhi, created to nurture, channel, and amplify creative expression among students and young people. Naqsh serves as a platform where art meets purpose—using literature, poetry, visual arts, theatre, and cultural dialogue as tools for reflection, expression, and social engagement.

As a node of SIO Delhi, Naqsh works to revive meaningful cultural traditions while encouraging contemporary artistic voices that engage with society, identity, ethics, and justice. The forum regularly organises mushairas, cultural gatherings, creative workshops, discussions, and art-based engagements, providing space for emerging artists and thinkers to express themselves responsibly and confidently.

Naqsh believes culture is not entertainment alone, but a powerful medium of ideas. Through its initiatives, it aims to cultivate aesthetic sensibility, critical thinking, and social consciousness—contributing to SIO Delhi’s broader vision of student development and constructive societal change.

SIO Delhi Condemns the Brutal Killing of 14-Year-Old Saahil
column5:
SIO Delhi strongly condemns the brutal and inhuman killing of 14-year-old Saahil in Shahdara, East Delhi. The fact that a minor boy was shot dead simply for picking up currency notes thrown during a wedding procession is both shocking and deeply disturbing. Such an act reflects a dangerous collapse of basic human values and a complete disregard for the sanctity of life.

We are pained to learn that the accused, a CISF officer, allegedly shot the child in a fit of rage while under the influence of alcohol. This horrific incident has shaken our conscience, and we stand firmly with Saahil’s family in this moment of unbearable grief. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the bereaved family and pray that Allah grants them patience and strength in this difficult time.

SIO Delhi

column4: SIO Delhi proudly organized Nahdah – Associates Camp 2025, a dynamic leadership and capacity-building program designed for our associates and emerging youth leaders. The camp focused on strengthening organizational understanding, enhancing practical skills, and fostering a spirit of commitment and teamwork. Through motivational sessions, skill workshops, mentoring circles, and collective reflection, participants were equipped to contribute more meaningfully within their units and communities. Nahdah – Associates Camp 2025 reinforced the values of service, ethical leadership, and purposeful action, preparing a renewed cohort of youth associates ready to drive positive change.

column3: Certificate Course on The Art of Public Speaking
column4: The Student Islamic Organisation of India (SIO), Delhi Zone, in collaboration with Shafi Moonis Academy of Resource Training and Development (SMART), organized a two-day certificate course on “Effective Public Speaking for Islamic Workers” from 31st August. The course was designed to enhance the communication skills of students and Islamic workers, focusing on clarity of thought, confidence, audience engagement, and ethical persuasion. Through structured training sessions, practical exercises, and expert guidance, participants learned the fundamentals of impactful public speaking and message delivery. The program aimed to equip attendees with essential skills to articulate ideas effectively, represent Islamic values responsibly, and engage diverse audiences with confidence and purpose.

column5:
There exists a fundamental right to live, yet Delhi’s air pollution stands in extreme violation of that very right. This crisis is neither natural nor accidental but is an outcome of governmental negligence. The current state of Delhi’s air quality has reached an alarming severity, costing countless lives each day and endangering public health at an alarming scale.

It is not an environmental issue anymore; rather, it has evolved into a full-fledged public health emergency. The Delhi government should recognize this crisis with the urgency it demands and impose very strict curbs. Let Delhi not choke and rescue our capital from this emergency.

Alfaz Khan
Convenor, Parisar Samvad
Delhi Chapter

SIO Delhi | Parisar Samvad

column4: SIO Delhi hosted the JAC Organisers Meet, a strategic and collaborative gathering of unit organisers and leadership teams from across the city. The meet provided a platform to align on upcoming initiatives, streamline organisational processes, and enhance coordination among the various JAC units. Through focused discussions, planning sessions, and experience-sharing dialogues, organisers strengthened their skills in mobilisation, event management, and grassroots engagement. The event reinforced a shared vision of effective teamwork, ethical leadership, and community-centered action, empowering organisers to implement high-impact programmes with clarity and unity.
